Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 10. The Bodhisattva Shows his Prowess in the Martial Arts

Then at another time, five hundred Shakya youths were outside, when Devadatta challenged them and knocked them down. The Bodhisattva approached, and Devadata grabbed him. The Bodhisattva hurled Devadatta far away without harming him and he landed on his back with his feet in the air. This is described in the Abhiniṣkramaṇa-sūtra.
Inscription - English:
The young prince hurled Devadatta away without harming him.

Manual - English: Devadatta (lhas sbyin) kills an elephant. Nanda (dga’ bo) catches an elephant by the tail, but loses it. The Buddha grabs an elephant and throws it far away. This scene should accord with common [understandings]. The Mahayana tradition has it that the Buddha throws an elephant with his big toe, but it is clear in the traditions of history (sngon 'byung) and Vinaya and so forth that Buddha throws an elephant with his hand. Many trees are cut. The trees fall immediately when others cut them down. The trees the Buddha cuts down won't fall for a long time. They only fall when winds blow them. Then, there is the archery contests drawn according to common conceptions.

Sun of Faith - English: Then the Licchavis of Vaishali acquired an elephant exceptional qualities.
A messanger said, "Shudhodana's son will become a Universal Ruler. This precious elephant has appeared through his power, and so we will offer it to him."
They travelled to Kapilavastu, brought the elephant before the palace gates, and waited.
Devadatta appeared and saw the the wonderful elephant. He asked, "What is this doing here?"
The messengers explained the story as before.
Devadatta became jealous. "You would give a great elephant to Siddhartha even before he has become a universal monarch?"
He slapped the elephant with the palm of his hand and killed it.
Nanda witnessed this and thought, "Devadatta has displayed is strength, and now so shall I."
Nanda caught hold of the elephant by its tail, dragged it seven paces and flung some distance away.
At that point the Bodhisattva appeared, looked at them, and asked what had happened.
They explained the elephant to him as before, and he thought, "Well, I shall awaken my powers as well."
Then with one hand he picked the elephant up by the tail and hurled him far away.
The elephant went over the seven city ramparts and the seven city moats, and landed more than a league away, making a hollow in the ground there.
This place became known as Elephant Hollow, and a stupa was made there.
The youths then went to the forest, where they practiced hacking down trees with swords, when the Bodhisattva arrived.
The others hacked at the tree, cutting wedges from above and below and when it was just cut through the tree came down.
The Bodhisattva did not chop his trees with wedges from above and below. He sliced straight through them and they did not fall as happened previously [with the youths].

They thought the Boddhisattva was unable to cut down the trees and ridiculed him saying, "He doesn't know how to cut anything." But as they began talking about him, a light breeze aroze and the trees cut by the Bodhisattva fell all together at once with a boom. Everyone was amazed.
Inscription - English: The trees cut by the Youth fall in the breeze.

Sun of Faith - English: Next, the Shakya youths held an archery competition.

They arranged as targets seven iron Tala trees, seven iron drums, and an iron figure of a boar. They each released an arrow. Devadatta's pierced one Tala tree. Nanda's pierced two. No one could could pierce more than that.
Inscription - English: Seven tala trees and five drums.

Sun of Faith - English: The Bodhisattva released an iron arrow, which pierced all the targets and continued flying even farther before striking the ground.
From the hole made by this arrow, serpent-spirits created a spring with perfect tasting water. Later this site known as Arrow Spring, and a stupa was built there.

Sun of Faith - English: The sooth-sayers predicted that were the Youth Siddhartha to refrain from renouncing the world for twelve years, he would definitely become a universal monarch.
Manual - English: Generally, the Buddha competes in up to five hundred categories of sports, but the traditions of History (sngon 'byung) and Vinaya are silent on the rest of the sport categories, so it is fine for us to leave off here.
